title: How to Make Chow Fun

steps.headline: Cut the beef.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife and slice the beef into thin strips along with the grain. Each strip should be about 2 inches (5 cm) wide. Cut each strip crosswise into 1/4 inch (0.6 cm) slices.

steps.headline: Marinate the beef.
steps.description: In a large bowl, whisk together the cornstarch, half the soy sauce, and the sesame oil. Add the beef, then stir well until all the meat is coated. Set the meat aside for 10 to 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Separate the noodles.
steps.description: Use your hands to separate the noodles into strips. If necessary, cut the noodles into 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) pieces. Note that the noodles may break into shorter pieces as you separate them. Use actual chow fun noodles if possible. If not, use any wide rice noodle.

steps.headline: Split the green onions.
steps.description: Cut the white portions off the green onions. Smack the white parts with the flat side of your knife, and place them in a bowl. You should also add the ginger and garlic to the same bowl, as well. Place the green portions of the onion in a separate bowl. Set aside.

steps.headline: Prepare the seasoning liquid.
steps.description: In a small bowl, whisk together the white pepper, sugar, remaining soy sauce, rice wine, oyster sauce, and water. Place this seasoning liquid near the stove, next to the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Heat the skillet.
steps.description: Place a large skillet or wok on the stove and heat it on high. Once hot, add 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of cooking oil. The skillet is hot enough when you can add a bead of water to it and watch it evaporate withing 1 to 2 seconds.

steps.headline: Stir-fry the aromatics.
steps.description: Place the ginger, garlic, and crushed sections of the green onion in the hot oil. Cook, stirring constantly, for 15 seconds or until the aroma gets drawn out. Once ready, carefully push the aromatics to one side of the pan.

steps.headline: Cook the beef.
steps.description: Add the beef to the pan in a flat layer. Sear it without stirring for 1 minute.

steps.headline: Add the bean sauce.
steps.description: Place the bean sauce in the skillet. Stir together with the beef and continue cooking for 30 seconds. Use black bean garlic sauce. If you cannot find any at the store, you can crush 2 Tbsp (30 ml) of cooked black beans with a fork and add that, instead. The beef should be cooked through, but be careful to avoid overcooking it. Once cooked, remove the beef, bean sauce, and aromatics. Set it aside. After removing the contents of the pan, rinse and dry the pan.

steps.headline: Cook the noodles and bean sprouts.
steps.description: Reheat the pan on high heat before adding another 2 Tbsp (30 ml) of oil. Add the noodles in a flat layer and sear, without stirring, for 2 minutes or until crusty. Add the bean sprouts and cook, stirring constantly, for another 1 minute or until the sprouts are soft. Note that some noodles may stick to the pan during this time.

steps.headline: Return everything to the pan.
steps.description: Place the beef and aromatics in the pan, along with any juices. Add the remaining green onions and stir to combine. Add the seasoning liquid and stir-fry for another 1 minute. When done, the beef should be well cooked and the sauce should be heated through.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Remove the chow fun from the heat and transfer it to a serving platter. Serve immediately.

steps.headline: Separate the rice noodles.
steps.description: Gently separate the rice noodles by hand. Trim them down to about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm), if necessary, and set them aside. If you can find actual chow fun noodles, use those. If not, use any wide rice noodle.

steps.headline: Slice and marinate the chicken.
steps.description:
Slice the chicken breast into thin strips using a sharp knife. Whisk together the sesame oil, black vinegar, rice wine, Chinese black bean paste/sauce, and 1-1/2 Tbsp (22.5 ml) of soy sauce. Toss the chicken in the mixture and let sit for 15 minutes
Chill the marinating chicken as it sits. You can mix the marinade in a large bowl and marinate the chicken in that, or you can combine everything in a large, heavy-duty resealable plastic bag. For an added kick of flavor, try a hot chili bean sauce with garlic.

steps.headline: Prepare the Chinese broccoli.
steps.description: Rinse the broccoli in running water and pat dry. Slice the vegetable into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces. Note that any hard stem pieces should be cut in half lengthwise, as well.

steps.headline: Heat the skillet.
steps.description: Place a large skillet or wok on the stove and heat it, dry, over medium-high. Let it warm up for 1 to 2 minutes. When ready, a small fleck of water should immediately begin to sizzle and evaporate once dropped into the skillet.

steps.headline: Stir-fry the chicken.
steps.description: Add the chicken to the hot, dry skillet and cook, stirring continuously, until completely cooked through. Remove the chicken once cooked and set it aside.

steps.headline: Cook the Chinese broccoli and peppers.
steps.description: Add both ingredients to the hot pan and cook, stirring constantly, for 3 minutes. The Chinese broccoli should be tender and bright green, and the pepper should be tender-crisp. When cooked, remove the vegetables from the heat and transfer them to the same dish as the cooked chicken.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and noodles.
steps.description: Pour the canola oil into the pan and heat it until it starts to shimmer. Add the garlic and cook, stirring constantly, for 1 minute or until it starts to brown and smell more fragrant. Add the noodles, as well, and cook for another 2 to 3 minutes. Stir the noodles by lifting them gently with tongs. The noodles should be a little soft when ready. They should also begin sticking to the pan.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining soy sauce.
steps.description: Add the rest of the soy sauce to the pan with the noodles and cook for another 1 minute. At this point, the noodles should be soft and tinted brown.

steps.headline: Return everything to the pan.
steps.description: Return the chicken and vegetables back to the pan and gently toss the ingredients together with your tongs. Keep on the heat until warmed through.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Remove from the heat and transfer to individual serving dishes. Garnish with sliced scallions and a drizzle of chili oil, if desired.

steps.headline: Heat the oil.
steps.description: Pour 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of vegetable oil into a large skillet or wok. Place the pan on the stove and turn the heat on to medium-high. Let the oil warm up for 1 to 2 minutes. Test the oil by dropping a bead of water into the pan. If the oil is hot enough, the water should sizzle immediately.

steps.headline: Stir-fry the meat and ginger.
steps.description: Add the slices of roast pork and ham to the oil. Place the minced ginger in the oil, as well. Cook for several minutes, stirring frequently, until the meat and ginger turn a light brown on each side. Note that the aroma of the ginger should also become notably stronger.

steps.headline: Add the other vegetables.
steps.description: Toss the carrots, celery, and onion into the hot oil. Cook the vegetables, along with the meat and ginger, until the vegetables are tender-crisp and the meat is half-done.

steps.headline: Add the bean sprouts.
steps.description: Place the bean sprouts in the ban and stir gently until warmed. Remove everything from the pan at this point.

steps.headline: Stir-fry the noodles.
steps.description: Add the remaining 2 Tbsp (30 ml) of vegetable oil to the hot pan. Place the noodles in the pan and cook, stirring constantly, for a full 1 minute. Use actual chow fun noodles if possible. If not, use any wide, short rice noodle. If you prefer crunchier edges, you can cook the noodles for a little while longer. Do not exceed an additional 1 to 2 minutes, though.

steps.headline: Return everything to the pan.
steps.description: Place the meat and vegetables back in the pan. Add the oyster sauce and stir, cooking just long enough to warm the sauce. Note that soy sauce can be used instead of oyster sauce if desired.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Garnish the chow fun with chopped green onions and remove the dish from the heat. Serve and enjoy.
